column5: @Jon - Please change colour of the Sr.No cell after you have taken the card away for conversion

column9: Text 1
column12: Text 2
column15: Text 3
column18: Text 4

column6: In this lesson, you will learn about the FinMango Money Cycle. The money cycle consists of a number of stages in personal finance.
column9: We can't enter the money cycle without having any money! It is crucial to earn money so we can then do something with it. However, earning money is not the final goal, we must also think about what to do with the money we earned.
column12: It may be tempting to spend all of our money on a new pair of sneakers; however, we must plan for the future and budget accordingly. Do you have a rainy day fund? If not, you should probably allocate some savings towards it. How about a trip somewhere? We have to save for that too.
column15: Once we have saved some of our money, we also need to manage and GROW our money. There are different ways to invest, whether that goes towards our education or growing a business.
column18: After saving and planting the money we earned, we can use what's left to spend. Spending money is perfectly OK as long as we are responsible and plan for the future.
column21: You can only spend money on so many fun things. Consider using the money towards something fulfilling that helps others. Without people who donate their money, we wouldn't be here!

column9: Debt to Equity is a financial ratio reflecting the relative contribution of creditors and shareholders to finance assets or employ capital in a company.
column12: The formula to find the ratio is Total liabilities/ Shareholders’ equity. It is found in the balance sheet of a company.
column15: Common debt-to-equity ratios from companies range from 0.0 to 3.0. Creditors often tolerate high debt-to-equity ratios in low financial risk industries. However, creditors demand lower debt-to-equity ratios in high financial risk industries.
column18: It is a measure of a company's financial leverage and its ability to repay its obligations.
column20: Why is the ratio important to a company?
column21: The ratio helps a company comprehend whether its capital structure is inclined towards debt or equity financing.

column9: Communism is an economic system advocating a classless system in which goods are owned communally and private property does not exist.
column12: Communism divides society into two classes: the proletariat (the working class), who make up the majority of the population within society who must work to survive while the bourgeoisie (the capitalist class), a small minority who derives profit from employing the working class through private ownership of the means of production.
column15: Production of necessary goods and services are shared and an individual’s contribution is based on their abilities and what they receive based solely on their needs.
column18: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels penned “The Communist Manifesto” in 1848.
column21: Soviet Union which collapsed in 1991 and China that has amended its economic system with some elements of capitalism were notable examples of communism.

column9: Socialism is an economic theory advocating the means of production, distribution, and exchange being owned and regulated by the community as a whole.
column12: The primary concern of socialist thinkers are exploitation of wage earners by the capitalist class, alienation of the workforce, and inefficiency. Socialism hence supports equal resource and wealth distribution and restricts competitive buying and selling.
column15: Government or worker cooperatives control all major means of production. Under this ideology production’s main purpose is use rather than profit. The use of resources and redistribution of taxes wealth is therefore decided by the state.
column21: Examples of socialism in today’s times include Cuba, Venezuela, and China. Examples of socialism in historic times include Germany and Soviet Union.

column9: Capitalism is an economic structure where means of production are privately owned for profit rather than the state. Private ownership of commodities hence provides greater economic freedom without government intervention.
column12: Free competition and competitive pricing is encouraged as supply and demand determines production resulting in a market economy instead of command economy.
column15: Laissez-faire capitalism allows people to be unrestrained as it functions without any checks or controls. Individuals decide where to invest, what to produce and at which prices.
column18: Elements of a capitalist economic system include economic freedom, consumer sovereignty, profit motive, and flexible labour markets.
column21: Few examples of capitalist economies include Singapore, the US and the UK.

column9: Supply Chain Management is the management of systems or processes that create goods and/or provide services.
column12: Entities part of the supply chain are producers, vendors, warehouses, transportation companies, distribution centers, and retailers. Functions in a supply chain vary from product development, marketing, operations, distribution, finance, and customer service.
column15: Benefits of Supply Chain Management include maximizing customer value, lowering costing while boosting profitability, achieving a sustainable competitive advantage, and ensuring the production cycle is faster.
column18: The organizational supply chain is linked together through physical flows (transformation, movement and storage of goods & services) and information flows (the day-to-day flow of goods and materials up and down along supply chain partners).
column21: Manufacturing and supply chain operations make Zara unique in its industry. The factories are connected to the Global Distribution Center by underground tunnels with high-speed monorails to move cut fabric for dyeing and assembling. The monorail system allows returning finished products to the center for direct shipment to stores.

column9: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) represents the size of a nation’s economy, which measures the value of the output of all goods and services produced within the country within a year.
column12: GDP can be measured either by the sum of what is purchased in the economy using the expenditures approach or by income earned on what is produced using the income approach.
column15: To avoid double counting—adding the value of output to the GDP more than once—GDP counts only final output of goods and services, not the production of intermediate goods or the value of labor in the chain of production.
column18:
Based on the four components of demand discussed earlier – consumption, C, investment, I, government, G, and trade balance, T (X-M) – GDP can be measured as follows:
GDP=C + I + G + (X - M)
column21:
Country ABC has exports of $35 million, government purchases of $900 million, business investment is $50 million, imports are $65 million, and consumption spending is $1,000 million. What is the dollar value of GDP?

GDP = C + I + G + (X - M)
GDP = $1,000 million + $50 million + $900 million + ($35 million -  $65 million) = $1,920 million

column9: The relationship between Supply & Demand is ultimately what determines the price of any given good or commodity that you buy.
column12: Demand is the number of people that are willing to buy a good or a service. Supply is the willingness to produce and sell a certain quantity of the good.
column15: Supply & Demand is the most important model used in Economics. At their core, Supply & Demand graphs convey: 1. How much of a good/service producers are willing to SUPPLY at any given price 2. How much of a good/service consumers DEMAND at any given price
column18:
Tatiana produces and sells orange juice. If she decides to sell her orange juice at $4, then 1,000 consumers will be willing to buy the juice and she will make a profit of $100. If she raises the price to $5, then only 600 consumers will be willing to buy the juice and she will make a profit of $60. If she lowers the price to $3, then 1,400 consumers will be willing to buy the juice and she will make a profit of $140.

Tatiana will choose to produce where she makes the most profit. Thus, Tatiana will price her juice at $3 and produce 1,400 cartons of orange juice.

column9: The addition of interest to the originally invested amount of a loan or deposit.
column12: Many banks use compounding to issue loans as well as a way to keep despoilers’ money at banks
column15:
Formula: A = P( 1 + r/n))^nt
	A = New principal sum
	P = Original principal sum
	r = Interest Rate (decimal)
	n = Number of times interest is compounded per unit “t”
	t = Time
column18:
Example: Suppose a principal amount of $1,00 is deposited in a bank paying an annual interest rate of 4.3%, compounded quarterly for 6 years.

P = 1500, 4 = 0.043 (4.3%), n = 4, t = 6

A = 1500*(1+0.043/4)^4*6 = 1938.84

column9: The profit margin ratio compares profit to sales, expressed as a percentage
column12: Companies use the profit margin ratio to express how well they are handling finances, including how much the business is making, general health of the business, and problems associated with the business
column15: Ratio of a company’s profit (sales - all expenses) / revenue
column18:
Example: $800,000 revenue
		($200,000) cost of goods sold
		$600,000 gross profit
		($400,000) other expenses
		$200,000 net income
Gross margin: $600,000 / $800,000 = 75%
Net margin: $200,000 / $800,000 = 25%

column9: Investing is the act of purchasing an item (asset) with the hope that over time the asset will appreciate value, and then be sold for a profit at a higher price.
column12: Investing is the allocation of resources (usually money) into assets or ventures to reap the benefit of value appreciation sometime in the future
column15: Investing is a key aspect of financial literacy. Value of money can depreciate over time even if we don't actually lose money due to inflation. Therefore, consistent, disciplined, investing is a great way to grow one's wealth and tackle inflation.
column18: Jacob just got to college and wants to start trading stocks. He has $500 right when he opens his first account to start buying and selling stocks. He buys 1 share of Netflix at $200 and 2 shares of Sony at $150 each. Within that first month of trading a share of Netflix went up to $230 and a share of Sony went up to $215. Jacob made $160 in his first month of trading with $500 to start.

column9: A mortgage is a type of loan typically used to purchase a home, in which the borrower must repay the money being borrowed with interest. The loan must be paid within the agreed amount of set payments, failure to do so gives the lender the right to take your property
column12: Mortgages are essential for the home buying process for a lot of people, unless buying in cash is an option. Mortgages provide home buyers flexible financing options that work around their income. Also, given that houses are high ticket size asstes (cost larger chunks of money), buyers more often than not require some help financing a home purchase.
column15: When a person is going to buy a $300,000 house, they could choose a flexible payment plan paying only 10% down payment paying the rest of the house in 25 to 30 years at a 5% interest rate. This allows individuals to afford an expensive home with fixed monthly payments.

column9: Opportunity cost is defined as the next best alternative that is given up when given a choice/undertaking an activity. In other words, an opportunity cost is the "potential benefit" a person could have derived from using their money in a different venture/investment, from the one that they actually pursued.
column12: In economics, it is useful to weigh all outcomes and choose the solution you think is best, and know what you are giving up
column15: Return from the most profitable investment (what’s lost) / Return from investment selected (what’s gained)
column18: A farmer chooses to plant wheat; the opportunity cost is planting a different crop, or an alternate use of the resources (land and farm equipment). That is, he could have planted a different crop to earn money or leased out his land to earn money. This "potential benefit" is his opportunity cost.

column9: Inflation is a general rise in the price level in an economy over a period of time, resulting in a sustained drop in the purchasing power of money.
column12: This means that the purchasing power of each dollar you own has decreased- you can buy less with each dollar than you previously could. This means that the price of the cereal you eat for breakfast, the gas you fill in your car, the shampoo you buy and so on has risen. In short, inflation affects everyone and everything in the economy. When your grandparents complain about rising prices, they're not wrong.
column15: It is measured by various indexes that can look at the prices of “baskets” or collections of related goods and services across the economy. Examples: Consumer Price Index, Producer Price Index
column18: Inflation, contrary to popular belief, is not always bad. In fact, inflation rates of about 2-3% the sign of a healthy and growing economy. Rising price levels can encourage consumers like you and me to buy goods now instead of putting them to later. For example, we may buy the next size of clothes for our kids now, the new washing machine now instead of later for fear that prices may continue rising.
column21: Inflation becomes bad when it occurs at very high rates. This is called Hyperinflation which involves large increases in price in a very short period of time. Most notably, this happened in Weimar Germany after the first World War. A famous image depicts people burning money to keep warm because the money was worth less than what it would cost to buy firewood. Barrels of money were used to buy one loaf of bread.

column9: A merger is when two firms agree to integrate their operations on a relatively co-equal basis. Acquisition is when a firm buys a controlling, or 100% interest in another firm to make the acquired firm a subsidiary business within its portfolio.
column12: Reasons for acquiring a firm include increased market power, overcoming entry barriers, lower risk than developing new products, increased diversification, and developing new capabilities.
column15: An example of a successful acquisition is Facebook & WhatsApp. It was the 9th largest M&A in 2014, costing $22 billion.
column18: An example of a failed merger due to integration issues is when eBay decided to buy Skype for $2.6 billion in 2005, only to sell it four years later for $1.9 billion. Like the Sprint-Nextel failure, eBay and Skype were unable to integrate their technological systems successfully.

column9: Bull and bear are words that are used to describe the conditions of the market— if it is gaining or declining in overall value. A bull market is used to describe the market when it going up and investors are optimistic. A bear market is when most of the stocks are declining and investor sentiment is negative.
column12: When putting your own money into the stock market, it is important to understand what is going on so that you can make smart decisions. If you know that the market is a bear market, you might wait to put money in because it is likely that that stock will keep going down until it starts to gain more value.
column15: Steve has been buying and trading stocks for the past 5 years. The market is starting to look more and more like a bear market every day. Steve does not like to have many shares during a bear market so he pulls out all of his shares other than a few that he thinks still will go up.
column18: Steve waits until he thinks that the market has hit bottom and then reinvests all of the money that he had in previously. Since he sold his shares at a higher price and then rebought them for cheaper, Steve will make more money off of his shares once the bear market trend reverses and turns into a bull market.

column9: A College 529 Savings Plan helps with pay for education expenses and has the benefit of being tax deducted and have no tax on withdrawals when you would like to simply take that money out and use it. There are two types of plans that are included in the 529 which is Savings Plan and Prepaid Tuition Plan.
column12: A 529 Savings plan is a great way to get involved with saving money for school early before the finances are a bigger problem in the future. Starting a account for a child is completely free and has not minimum cash amount in the account to start.
column15: The savings plan will create an account for the child to strictly save and build as much money as contributed by the parents as they want. The prepaid tuition plan will lock in rates of college tuition at that time and allow parents to contribute the money, but does not cover room and board.
column18: Ralph and Donna want to start investing money into an account for their child’s future college expenses and schooling expenses along the way. Ralph and Donna will invest in a 529 savings account for their baby because they are unsure where the baby will attend college in the future. Locking in tuition with a prepaid tuition plan will prevent that from happening. They decide to contribute $500 monthly until their baby is ready for college.

column9: Diversification is the action of creating a investing portfolio with many different companies rather than just a single type of company that all share the same traits. This is a risk management strategy which means it is safer to have other assets to rely on if the market fluctuates negatively towards a type of market in a period of time
column12: Diversification is a great way to stay safe with your money when investing. Diversification is completely up to the buyer when it comes to investing in a stock. Creating an account to invest is free and there are many tips within those accounts to get you started on learning what different categories of companies to diversify in.
column15: Roger decides to invest $800 in stock for the year 2020. He is inclined to invest in apple as they are on a decline at $172.37 per stock during the COVID-19 pandemic. As Roger scans through the market, he finds Tesla is down to $620.23 per stock. Roger decides to invest his money in both and keep the remaining buying power for later. Having a dip in both companies rather than just one, Roger has secured a back up in case one stock underperforms more during the period of time he owns it.

column9: Bonds are a method of getting a loan for a large amount of money that comes with a fixed amount of interest that is determined by how long the bond has “matured”. Bonds are typically dealt between companies and are used for big project and operation costs.
column12: Bonds are used for businesses and companies to gather a large amount of money quickly to turn around and use it for city projects or running their operations. Bonds have a “coupon price” that comes with a set amount of time that the bond will exist for. The coupon price tacks on “Interest” for the borrower and by the end of the bond, the lender will walk away with more than they came with. That also increases the price of the bond itself. Borrowers can make a quick turn around to not steer off track of their business plans.
column15: Meijer is in need of money to establish a new store in Milwaukee. They are set up to start building in 2 months, but have not been able to generate enough funds to have construction operations covered right away. They establish a bond with Walmart that will have a coupon price of 0.13 for 2 years. Their operations are covered for the upcoming constructions and both companies agree that the payment will be established in 2 years.

column9: Risk tolerance is the amount of loss an investor will be prepared to face if they pursue certain investment decisions. This will help how they build their portfolio of investments for the future with low-risk being more conservative investing and high-risk going after potential large losses or big gains.
column12: Risk tolerance is used to determine the loss a person might incur if they went down a certain investment route. Factors that heavily influence these decisions is Time, Goals, and Portfolio size. Time is always competing against you because we can always calculate when a investment might appreciate or drop, but other factors of the market could change that instantaneously. Being time conscious of when to buy and sell also goes into the goals that a investor has. Is this long term or for a quick turnaround?
column15: Those questions are important for how much money they are seeking out of this investment. Portfolio size creates a cushion for risk tolerance because people can easily determine if they should go into this or if they even need to. Looking at a portfolio can show an investor if they are in desperate need of these funds at all or they can invest in other things that could show quicker success for their portfolio at the time.
column18: Jonathan has been involved in mutual funds and now wants to branch out in the stock market. He wants to invest money into Tesla and see how much he could turn around in a small amount of time. Looking at the previous data shown by Tesla, they have small spurts of appreciation, but they are more consistent long term. This is difficult for Jonathan’s plan of having quick profit and he decides to invest in multiple other companies for the time being to get his results instead.

column9: Asset allocation is the process of portioning out a portfolio’s assets. To avoid risk and matching assets to an individual’s goals and investment timeline can greatly benefit the process of investing and improve quality of assets as well. A great investment strategy that creates better opportunities for any investor.
column12: Asset allocation is useful when starting to set up a portfolio to invest because everyone has different goals when going into investing. It sets the person up to align with their goals instead of wasting time with investments that don’t help their cause. Risk tolerance is very much considered in this process and it leads the investor to the correct goals with much less risk if needed or increased risk, but chances of higher appreciation in the long run.
column15: Susan has decided to work with a financial advisor to get her investment portfolio started. She decides that she wants to be in for the long haul and have her investments appreciate in the future for a retirement fund. Her financial advisor advises her to use asset allocation to separate her long term investments from investments on the market that are considered “short-term stocks”. Her risk tolerance is low and she wants to stay comfortable while her portfolio grows. Asset allocation adjusts to her comfortability and creates a portfolio of long term investments with a low risk.

column9: Indexing is where you create a portfolio that focuses mainly on tracking of the performance of a market’s index. The most common index that is tracked is the S&P Index 500. Indexing can also refer to using metrics to measure the performance of economic activity.
column12: The method of indexing is most useful when an investor is interested in tracking data from a market index to follow its success and mimic their portfolio to also achieve that success. People can also calculate purchasing power of the US dollar or rate of inflation using the CPI or the Consumer Price Index.
column15: Adam is deciding to look into mutual funds and wants the most security with low risks. He decides that he likes the way that the S&P Index 500 is performing. He uses the Consumer Price Index to calculate the rate of inflation before getting into indexing the S&P Index 500. He also uses the CPI to adjust his interest rates for these investments and realizes the numbers work well with his plan and he decides he wants to mimic the performance of the market for the most success in his goals.

column9: The profit and loss (P&L) statement is a financial statement that summarizes the revenues, costs, and expenses incurred during a specified period, usually a fiscal quarter or year.
column12: These records provide information about a company's ability or inability to generate profit by increasing revenue, reducing costs, or both. Some refer to the P&L statement as income statement.
column15: The P&L statement is one of three financial statements every public company issues quarterly and annually, along with the balance sheet and the cash flow statement.
column18: It is important to compare P&L statements from different accounting periods, as the changes in revenues, operating costs, R&D spending, and net earnings over time are more meaningful than the numbers themselves.

column9: A balance sheet is a financial statement that reports a company's assets, liabilities and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time, and provides a basis for computing rates of return and evaluating its capital structure
column12: It is a financial statement that provides a snapshot of what a company owns and owes, as well as the amount invested by shareholders.
column15: if a company takes out a five-year, $4,000 loan from a bank, its assets (specifically, the cash account) will increase by $4,000. Its liabilities (specifically, the long-term debt account) will also increase by $4,000, balancing the two sides of the equation. If the company takes $8,000 from investors, its assets will increase by that amount, as will its shareholders' equity.
column18: All revenues the company generates in excess of its expenses will go into the shareholders' equity account. These revenues will be balanced on the assets side, appearing as cash, investments, inventory, or some other asset.

column9: Cash flow is the net amount of cash and cash-equivalents being transferred into and out of a business. At the most fundamental level, a company’s ability to create value for shareholders is determined by its ability to generate positive cash flows, or more specifically, maximize long-term free cash flow.
column12: Positive cash flow indicates that a company is adding to its cash reserves, allowing it to reinvest in the company, pay out money to shareholders, or settle future debt payments.
column15: Free cash flow, a measure commonly used by analysts to assess a company's profitability, represents the cash a company generates after accounting for cash outflows to support operations and maintain its capital assets.
column18: Cash flow comes in three forms: operating, investing, and financing. Operating cash flow includes all cash generated by a company's main business activities. Investing cash flow includes all purchases of capital assets and investments in other business ventures. Financing cash flow includes all proceeds gained from issuing debt and equity as well as payments made by the company.

column9: An asset is a resource with economic value that an individual, corporation, or country owns or controls with the expectation that it will provide a future benefit. Assets are reported on a company's balance sheet and are bought or created to increase a firm's value or benefit the firm's operations.
column12: An asset can be thought of as something that, in the future, can generate cash flow, reduce expenses, or improve sales, regardless of whether it's manufacturing equipment or a patent.
column15:
Current assets are assets that are expected to be converted to cash within a year. Current assets are separated from other resources because a company relies on its current assets to fund ongoing operations and pay current expenses.
 Examples of current assets include:
1)Cash and cash equivalents
2)Accounts receivable
3)Prepaid expenses
4)Inventory
5)Marketable securities
column18:
Noncurrent assets are those that are considered long-term, where their full value won't be recognized until at least a year. Since noncurrent assets have a useful life for a very long time, companies spread their costs over several years. This process helps avoid huge losses during the years when capital expansions occur. Examples of non-current assets include: 1)Land
2)Property, plant, and equipment (PP&E)
3)Trademarks
4)Long-term investments
5)Goodwill
column21: The key difference between current and noncurrent assets and liabilities, which are all listed on the balance sheet, is their timeline for use or payment.

column9: A liability is something a person or company owes, usually a sum of money. Liabilities are settled over time through the transfer of economic benefits including money, goods, or services.In general, a liability is an obligation between one party and another not yet completed or paid for.
column12: Liabilities are usually considered short term (expected to be concluded in 12 months or less) or long term (12 months or greater). Liabilities are also known as current or non-current depending on the context.
column15: For example, in most cases, if a wine supplier sells a case of wine to a restaurant, it does not demand payment when it delivers the goods. Rather, it invoices the restaurant for the purchase to streamline the dropoff and make paying easier for the restaurant. The outstanding money that the restaurant owes to its wine supplier is considered a liability.
column18: Noncurrent liabilities, also known as long-term liabilities, are obligations listed on the balance sheet not due for more than a year. Various ratios using noncurrent liabilities are used to assess a company’s leverage, such as debt-to-assets and debt-to-capital. Examples of noncurrent liabilities include: 1)Long-Term loans 2)Lease obligations 3) Bonds Payable 4) Deferred Revenue
column21: Current liabilities are a company's short-term financial obligations that are due within one year or within a normal operating cycle (time it takes a company to purchase inventory and convert it to cash from sales). Examples of current liabilities include: (1) Accounts Payable (2) Short-term Debt (3) Dividends Payable

column9: Equity represents the value that would be returned to a company’s shareholders if all of the assets were liquidated and all of the company's debts were paid off.
column12: We can also think of equity as a degree of residual ownership in a firm or asset after subtracting all debts associated with that asset. Equity represents the shareholders’ stake in the company, identified on a company's balance sheet.
column15: Shareholders Equity = Total Assets −Total Liabilities
column18: Equity is used in several key financial ratios such as ROE.
column21: Shareholder equity can be either negative or positive. If positive, the company has enough assets to cover its liabilities. If negative, the company's liabilities exceed its assets; if prolonged, this is considered balance sheet insolvency. Typically, investors view companies with negative shareholder equity as risky or unsafe investments.

column9: Monetary policy refers to the measures adopted by the central bank to regulate the supply of money and cost of credit in the economy.
column12: Thus, monetary policy of a country mainly relates to the following: a) The volume of money b) The availability of credit and c) The cost of borrowing, i.e., rate of interest
column15: Monetary policy seeks to influence total demand by influencing the amount and cost of credit available to the borrowers. The government may increase or decrease total demand in the economy by making more or less funds available and by proving them at cheaper or expensive rates.
column18: The 3 primary objectives of monetary policies are the management of inflation or unemployment, and maintenance of currency exchange rates.
column21: Central banks use various tools to implement monetary policies. The widely utilized policy tools include: (1) Interest Rate Adjgustment (2) Change reserve requirements (3) Open market operations
column23: A monetary policy that aims to increase the money supply in the economy by decreasing interest rates, purchasing government securities by central banks, and lowering the reserve requirements for banks. An expansionary policy lowers unemployment and stimulates business activities and consumer spending. The overall goal of the expansionary monetary policy is to fuel economic growth.
column26: The goal of a contractionary monetary policy is to decrease the money supply in the economy. It can be achieved by raising interest rates, selling government bonds, and increasing the reserve requirements for banks. The contractionary policy is utilized when the government wants to control inflation levels.

column9: Equity, typically referred to as shareholders' equity (or owners equity' for privately held companies), represents the amount of money that would be returned to a company’s shareholders if all of the assets were liquidated and all of the company's debt was paid off in the case of liquidation.
column12: We can also think of equity as a degree of residual ownership in a firm or asset after subtracting all debts associated with that asset.
column15: Equity Investments allow investors to hold partial ownerships of the company. When you buy the stock of a company, you're technically an owner of the company.
column18: Equity investments come in various forms, you can either buy stocks of individual companies or buy them in a group ( i.e Mutual Funds)
column21: Equity usually carries a lot more risk than its counterparts but also provides equally high returns.

column9: real estate includes the physical surface of the land, what lies above and below it, what is permanently attached to it, plus all the rights of ownership—including the right to possess, sell, lease, and enjoy the land.
column12: Real property shouldn't be confused with personal property, which encompasses all property that doesn't fit the definition of real property. The primary characteristic of personal property is that it's movable.
column15: Examples include vehicles, boats, furniture, clothing, and smartphones. Real estate and other physical assets are considered an asset class that offers protection against inflation.
column18: The tangible nature of such assets also leads to them being considered as more of a “real” asset. In that respect, they differ from assets that exist only in the form of financial instruments, such as derivatives.
